title: Does your age affect your political views?
intro: Does our age affect the way we vote? And do our political views change as we get older? It's what Sam and Neil are discussing in 6 Minute English - as well as teaching some related vocabulary.
this_week_question: What was the first UK general election in which 18-year-olds could vote?
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: having a clear and simple moral view of how things should be
the policies of a political party or politician
the situation as it is now
the idea of being realistic and practical about what can be achieved.

transcript.text: Note: This is not a word for word transcript

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English, I'm Neil.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: And I'm Sam.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Sam, do you remember the first time you voted?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: No I don’t, but I remember being very keen to do it. It would have been the first election after my 18th birthday.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So, over the many, many, many years since then …

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: … eh, not so much with the ‘manys’ if you don’t mind Neil!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: In the very, very few years since then …

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: That’s more like it!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: In the years since then, have your political views changed very much?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: I think my political views are a lot better informed now. I think the decisions I make are based on a better understanding of the political situation – but I still generally agree with the same things I did when I was younger, I think.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: There is a belief that as we get older we become more right-wing in our political views and opinions. Is this true and if so, why? We’ll be finding out a little bit more about this, but first a question. What was the first UK general election in which 18-year-olds could vote? A: 1929 B: 1950, or C: 1970 So, what do you reckon then Sam?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Well, they were all before my time. I’m going to say 1950 – that sounds about right – it was the decade in which teenagers were invented, after all!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK. Well, I will reveal the answer later in the programme. James Tilley is a professor of politics at the University of Oxford. He appeared recently on BBC Radio 4’s programme Analysis and was asked why, if it is true, do we become more right-wing as we get older. What does he think?

transcript.author: Professor James Tilley
transcript.text: Professor James Tilley The question that age affects our political views is a tricky one. I think probably the most plausible explanation is that people just generally become a bit more resistant to change as they get older and I think also that they also tend to perhaps, become less idealistic .

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So, what reasons does he give?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Well, he talks about what he thinks are the most plausible explanations. Plausible is an adjective which means something is believable; it’s reasonable and it makes sense.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And what are the plausible explanations?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Well, he says that generally, as we get older, we like to have more stability in our lives, we don’t like change, in fact we are resistant to change. That means we are against change. When we are younger we might like the idea of revolution, we might be very idealistic . This means, for example, we might think that we can and should change the world to make things better. This would cause big changes in the world which when we are older and more settled in our lives, do not seem like such a good idea.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Let’s listen again.

transcript.author: Professor James Tilley
transcript.text: Professor James Tilley The question that age affects our political views is a tricky one. I think probably the most plausible explanation is that people just generally become a bit more resistant to change as they get older and I think also that they also tend to become less idealistic .

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Professor Tilley goes on to explain more about why being resistant to change might lead people to support more right-wing policies.

transcript.author: Professor James Tilley
transcript.text: So, if parties on the right represent a platform which is perhaps more favourable to the status quo , it’s perhaps more about pragmatism than it is about idealism, then that might be more attractive to older people than younger people.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So, what is seen as the appeal of moving to the right?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Political parties have a particular set of policies. This is sometimes known as their platform . Professor Tilley says that if their platforms support the status quo , they might be more attractive to older people. The status quo is a Latin phrase we use in English to refer to the situation as it is now – that is, one that is not going to change. Traditionally it’s parties of the centre right that seem to be more supportive of the status quo .

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So, as we get older he says our political views are less about idealism and more about pragmatism . Pragmatism is being practical and realistic about what can be achieved and how it can be achieved.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: But of course this doesn’t apply to everyone and just because people seem to move more to the right as they get older doesn’t mean that they completely change their politics.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Let’s hear Professor Tilley again.

transcript.author: Professor James Tilley
transcript.text: So, if parties on the right represent a platform which is perhaps more favourable to the status quo , it’s perhaps more about pragmatism than it is about idealism, then that might be more attractive to older people than younger people.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Right, let’s get the answer to our question. What was the first UK general election in which 18-year-olds could vote? A: 1929 B: 1950, or C: 1970 Sam, what did you say?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: I thought it was 1950.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, you’re wrong I’m afraid. The correct answer is1970. 18-year-olds have been allowed to vote in the UK since 1969 and the first general election after then was in 1970. So, a bit later than you thought, Sam, but congratulations to anyone who did get that right. OK, let’s remind ourselves of our vocabulary.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Yes, first we had plausible . An adjective that means ‘believable and possible’.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Being resistant to something means you are against it and don’t want it to happen.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: If you are idealistic you have a clear and simple moral view of how things should be.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: This contrasts with one of our other words, pragmatism , this noun is the idea of being realistic and practical about what can be achieved.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: A platform can describe the policies and ideas of a political party or politician. And the status quo is the unchanging situation as it is now.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, thank you Sam. That’s all from us in this programme. Do join us again and if you can’t wait you can find lots more from BBC Learning English online, on social media and on our app. Goodbye!

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Bye!
